🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! Requisition Name: AWS Network Cloud Infra EngineerDuration: 12+ months Services Location: TX/Dallas Acceptance Criteria:Onsite workMust be willing to work on our W2H1 Transfers are welcome bob@vinsari.com Description Of Services:AWS Cloud Engineer with networking skillset What You will need (Qualifications) Atleast 3+ years of experience in AWS with hands-on contribution in DevOps engineering. Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. Strong Experience in building CI/CD (Gitlab, Jenkins) and deployment automation. Good practical Linux / Windows-based systems administration skills in a Cloud or Virtualized environment Experience working on FedRamp compliant projects is a plus. Palo Alto & Panaroma Skillset requirements:- Design and architect Palo Alto firewall solutions for AWS cloud-based infrastructures based on business requirements and security best practices. Ability to independently deploy Palo Alto firewalls & Panorama in cloud environments using IaC automation, ensuring proper network segmentation and security zones. Strong hands-on experience using Panorama to configure security policies, NAT rules, VPN tunnels, and other firewall settings to protect cloud assets. Implement high availability and failover configurations for firewall devices. Develop and enforce security policies, including threat prevention, URL filtering, application control, and user identification. Ability to Integrate Panorama with other security tools and systems, such as SIEM platforms, to enhance threat detection and response capabilities. Palo Alto Networks certifications (e.g., PCNSA, PCNSE) are highly desirable. 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! إليك يارب أشكو ضعف قوتي، وقلة حيلتي، وهواني على الناس. يا رب، أسألك من فضلك ورحمتك، فإنه لا يملكها إلا أنت.يا رب، تعلم أن التوفيق والنتائج منك وحدك، وأن ما عليّ إلا السعي والاجتهاد. وأنا أسعى وأجتهد، ولكن الصبر وحده لا يكفي، فمن اعولهم لا يستطيعون الانتظار.لم أتأخر عن سماع أي نصيحة، ولم أبخل بأي جهد، ولكن الفرص الحقيقية لم تأتِ بعد. منذ شهور وأنا بلا عمل، والأمور تزداد تعقيدًا. الضغوط المادية والاحتياجات اليومية تثقل كاهلي، والمصاريف والفواتير والأولاد والمدارس والإيجارات والغلاء والأمراض والأعياد تزيد من همي. والضغط النفسي والاجتماعي يمزقني، ولا أرى جنيهًا واحدًا من كدي وتعبي.أرجو ، ألا تتجاهل ندائي، وتفاعل معي بجدية، لعل الله يحدث بعد ذلك أمرًا. أرجو الدعم أو التوصية أو إعادة النشر. وأنا جاهز للعمل فورًا، وأسعد بتلقي أي استفسارات حول خبراتي ومهاراتي، ومستعد لتعلم المزيد.عمرو شعراوي  +201005802137 Phone , what's up hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#applicationcoordinator hashtag#d365fo hashtag#erpimplementation hashtag#CRM hashtag#retail hashtag#dynamics365fo hashtag#businessanalysis hashtag#egypt hashtag#businessapplications hashtag#hiringjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#humanresourcesrecruiting hashtag#itdirectors hashtag#itjobopportunity hashtag#itjobsearch hashtag#alexandria hashtag#helpforjob hashtag#support hashtag#itconsulting hashtag#jobseeker hashtag#sqlserverdba hashtag#jobvacancies hashtag#jobs hashtag#employment hashtag#jobs2024 hashtag#erpcoordinator hashtag#erpprojectmanager hashtag#jobseekeradvice hashtag#working hashtag#hiring hashtag#opportunity hashtag#vacancies hashtag#caeeer hashtag#recruiting hashtag#jobsinegypt hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#job hashtag#hotjobs hashtag#jobhunt hashtag#dreamjob hashtag#freelancejobs hashtag#dubaijobseeker hashtag#dreamjob hashtag#saudijobs hashtag#saudiarabiajobs hashtag#emiratescareershashtag#ساعد_تتساعد

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! إليك يارب أشكو ضعف قوتي، وقلة حيلتي، وهواني على الناس. يا رب، أسألك من فضلك ورحمتك، فإنه لا يملكها إلا أنت.يا رب، تعلم أن التوفيق والنتائج منك وحدك، وأن ما عليّ إلا السعي والاجتهاد. وأنا أسعى وأجتهد، ولكن الصبر وحده لا يكفي، فمن اعولهم لا يستطيعون الانتظار.لم أتأخر عن سماع أي نصيحة، ولم أبخل بأي جهد، ولكن الفرص الحقيقية لم تأتِ بعد. منذ شهور وأنا بلا عمل، والأمور تزداد تعقيدًا. الضغوط المادية والاحتياجات اليومية تثقل كاهلي، والمصاريف والفواتير والأولاد والمدارس والإيجارات والغلاء والأمراض والأعياد تزيد من همي. والضغط النفسي والاجتماعي يمزقني، ولا أرى جنيهًا واحدًا من كدي وتعبي.أرجو ، ألا تتجاهل ندائي، وتفاعل معي بجدية، لعل الله يحدث بعد ذلك أمرًا. أرجو الدعم أو التوصية أو إعادة النشر. وأنا جاهز للعمل فورًا، وأسعد بتلقي أي استفسارات حول خبراتي ومهاراتي، ومستعد لتعلم المزيد.عمرو شعراوي  +201005802137 Phone , what's up hashtag#jobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#applicationcoordinator hashtag#d365fo hashtag#erpimplementation hashtag#CRM hashtag#retail hashtag#dynamics365fo hashtag#businessanalysis hashtag#egypt hashtag#businessapplications hashtag#hiringjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#humanresourcesrecruiting hashtag#itdirectors hashtag#itjobopportunity hashtag#itjobsearch hashtag#alexandria hashtag#helpforjob hashtag#support hashtag#itconsulting hashtag#jobseeker hashtag#sqlserverdba hashtag#jobvacancies hashtag#jobs hashtag#employment hashtag#jobs2024 hashtag#erpcoordinator hashtag#erpprojectmanager hashtag#jobseekeradvice hashtag#working hashtag#hiring hashtag#opportunity hashtag#vacancies hashtag#caeeer hashtag#recruiting hashtag#jobsinegypt hashtag#jobsearch hashtag#job hashtag#hotjobs hashtag#jobhunt hashtag#dreamjob hashtag#freelancejobs hashtag#dubaijobseeker hashtag#dreamjob hashtag#saudijobs hashtag#saudiarabiajobs hashtag#emiratescareershashtag#ساعد_تتساعد

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney

Strong track record of implementing AWS services in a variety of distributed computing environments (Design and implementation experience and Cloud Networking). Strong experience on AWS Infrastructure services (EC2, ELB, RDS, Route53, S3, vpc, vpn, tgw, cloudwatch, cloudtrail, eventbridge, etc. Large scale implementation and migration experience of Data Center to Cloud Infrastructure automation through DevOps scripting (Ansible, Shell, Python, Ruby, PowerShell) Hands on experience in terraform IaC deployments. Good practical Linux / Windows-based systems administration skills in a Cloud or Virtualized environment Experience working on FedRamp compliant projects is a plus. Ability to independently deploy Palo Alto firewalls & Panorama in cloud environments using IaC automation, ensuring proper network segmentation and security zones. Palo Alto Networks certifications (e.g., PCNSA, PCNSE) are highly desirable. 🟡The Best Roadmap for Full-Stack Development in 2025 🚀So, you want to be a Full-Stack Developer in 2025?Good news: Companies LOVE full-stack devs.Bad news: You might get stuck fixing both frontend & backend bugs at 3 AM.But don’t worry, I’ve got the ultimate roadmap for you! 🔥🔹 Step 1: Learn the Basics (1-2 Months)📌 HTML, CSS, JavaScript – The foundation of web development.📌 Git & GitHub – Because "works on my machine" isn't an excuse.📌 Basic Data Structures & Algorithms – Don't skip this, trust me!🔹 Step 2: Master Frontend (2-3 Months)🎨 React.js (or Next.js) – Companies want modern frameworks, not just plain HTML.🎨 Redux / State Management – Because "lifting state up" isn’t always enough.🎨 Tailwind / Bootstrap – So your website doesn’t look like it was built in 2010.🔹 Step 3: Master Backend (3-4 Months)🛠 Node.js with Express (or Django, Spring Boot, etc.) – Pick one, but master it.🛠 Databases: MongoDB / PostgreSQL / MySQL – No, Excel sheets don’t count as databases.🛠 Authentication (JWT, OAuth) – Security isn’t optional.🔹 Step 4: Learn DevOps & Cloud (1-2 Months)☁️ Docker & Kubernetes – Not just for big companies, but a game-changer.☁️ CI/CD Pipelines – Automate everything!☁️ AWS / GCP / Azure – Knowing how to deploy isn’t a bonus, it’s a requirement.🔹 Step 5: Build Real Projects (Ongoing)💻 Clone popular apps like Zomato, Swiggy, or Netflix.💻 Contribute to Open Source – GitHub > Resume (Remember this).💻 Build a portfolio – Hiring managers love devs who show their work.📌 Pro Tips:✅ Be consistent – You don’t need 10 hours a day, but you need daily practice.✅ Don’t learn 50 things at once – Master one stack before jumping to another.✅ Google & Stack Overflow are your best friends – But don’t copy-paste blindly!✅Feel free to use OpenAI, BLACKBOX.AI, CodePen for Help.✅Use resources from GeeksforGeeks, W3Schools.com, freeCodeCamp, Codeword, Love Babbar, PW (PhysicsWallah), Apni Kaksha for free resources 😉 Full-stack development isn’t just about coding—it’s about problem-solving.Are you learning full-stack? Drop a 🔥 "YES" in the comments! 🚀 My First Azure DevOps Project – Migrating GitHub CI Pipelines to Azure Pipelines!For the past few months, I’ve been skilling up in DevOps, learning the ins and outs of CI/CD, cloud automation, and infrastructure as code. And today, I’m excited to share a milestone—completing my first Azure DevOps project! 🎉This project involved migrating a Voting App’s CI pipeline from GitHub to Azure Pipelines. While the concept seemed straightforward, implementing it hands-on brought some unexpected challenges (and valuable lessons)!🔹 Project OverviewThe Voting App consists of multiple microservices working together:✅ A Python-based voting service✅ A Redis cache for managing votes✅ A .NET worker that processes the votes✅ A PostgreSQL database for storing results✅ A Node.js result service to display the outcome🚧 Challenges I Faced & Lessons LearnedLike any DevOps project, things didn’t go smoothly on the first try! Here are a few errors I encountered and what I learned:❌ Docker Build Failures🔹 Error: “The process ‘/usr/bin/docker’ failed with exit code 1.”🔹 Cause: A required argument wasn’t passed in the Dockerfile of the main branch in the cloned repository.🔹 Fix: Updated the Dockerfile to ensure all required arguments were properly defined.❌ YAML Indentation Errors🔹 Problem: Pipelines failed due to incorrect indentation in the azure-pipelines.yml file.🔹 Fix: Carefully corrected the YAML structure, ensuring proper indentation and syntax. Lesson learned—YAML is super picky!At first, these errors felt frustrating, but debugging them taught me more than any tutorial ever could.🎯 Key TakeawayThe best way to learn DevOps is to get hands-on, break things, and fix them! This project helped me gain deeper insights into CI/CD automation, YAML syntax, Docker builds, and Azure Pipelines—skills that are critical for any DevOps Engineer.🙏 A Huge Thanks!A special shoutout to Abhishek Veeramalla explaining DevOps concepts in such a simple and clear way! His content has been incredibly helpful throughout my learning journey. 🙌📸 Attaching some screenshots of what went wrong and the end result of pipelines running.Excited to explore more projects and learn more. hashtag#Azure hashtag#Azuredevops hashtag#devops hashtag#CICD hashtag#Devopsjourney
